title: Between 11 September 2019 and 31 October 2019, what will be the widest closing spread of the yield on 10-year Treasurys below the yield on 2-year Treasurys?
possible_answers: The 10 yr yield will not close at or lower than the 2 yr yield
The 10 Yr yield closing between .01 and .10 lower than the 2 Yr yield, inclusive
The 10 Yr yield closing more than .10 lower than the 2 Yr yield
correct_answer: The 10 yr yield will not close at or lower than the 2 yr yield
preds: Between 11 September 2019 and 31 October 2019, what will be the widest closing spread of the yield on 10-year Treasurys below the yield on 2-year Treasurys?  Being late to the party sometimes has advantages.

The spread has risen to 21 bps today.
Both yields have been rising in tandem, in spite of expectations of Fed lowering benchmark rates on Wednesday.
Already baked into the markets??

for most of October their were cracks appearing in the international economy so there was still a chance that the yield curve could invert. However recent strength in Germany and a purported US/China deal has reduced that possibility to negligible for this time frame.
Updating in the line of https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/917652 but with the latest data.

The 10-2 year treasury spread yield is 0.19 % as of today. 10 year treasuries continue to out perform 2 year treasuries. Notwithstanding the uncertainty of Brexit. While this will continue to play out over the week, I'll revise up to 100 %. That 10 year yield will not close at or less than 2 year yields by 31 October.
Updating for current level and time left.

My current extrapolations suggest that there is little chance of the spread closing below the 2 yr yield - unless there is a jump due to some surprise in the bond market that my TES model can't capture.  My model says 100% that the 10 yr will not close <= than the 2 year.  However, I'm leaving my forecast the same because stating 0% probability for 10 below 2 is saying that I think it is impossible.  Using a version of Sherman Kent's WEP Probability scale, I think the 10 yr bond is almost certain to close above the 2 year (ie, positive spread), but it is not impossible to be surprised.

Updated prediction from 21/10/2019 data. First I compute the probability of filling the buckets with a random walk model diff(day+1) = diff(day) + random_gaussian (mu=0, sigma) with sigma = 0.035, which might be too high (but is consistent with the data during the last six months). After 10000 random runs I get 96.1, 3.7 and 0.2 for each bucket. Now I add a new factor: I feel that my first predictions completely overestimated the probability of an inversion of the yield curve, because I simply random-walked the problem.  It happens that there is probably a strong psychological aversion to the inversion, which I take into account by halving the probabilities for 0.1 and above. In this way I arrive to the 98, 2, 0 that I used.

The 10-2 year treasury spread yield is 0.18 % as of today. 10 year treasuries continue to out perform 2 year treasuries. On the other hand, it's speculated that this has been in relation to the markets hoping for resolution of Brexit. While this will continue to play out over the week, I'll revise up to 99 %. That 10 year yield will not close at or less than 2 year yields by 31 October.
~20 basis point spread between 10 and 2. +6% to 'will not'.
Used Bayes, though, will add my working later; however, the forecast for recession over the next 12 months is 34 %. That supports the performance of 10 year treasuries over 2 year treasuries.
The 10-2 spread is now 17 basis points, 1.75 and 1.58 respectively. +6% to 'will not' -5% to 'between' -1% to 'more than'.

Despite reported Fed intervention on the very short end of the yield curve (1/2/3/6 mo)  - curve remains inverted as per Daily Treasury Yield Rates on Treasury.gov.
Conceivably a chance of collapse in the spread in the 10 days remaining if there is a return to Treasuries from some world event.
Otherwise, with the spread growing to +18 bps from +12 bps this month  - indicating  gradual firming.
Still using a random walk model diff(day+1) = diff(day) + random_gaussian (mu=0, sigma) with sigma = 0.035, which might be too high. After 10000 random runs I get the probabilities above.
Updating to incorporate current spread and passing of another week.
Re-ran forecast based on most recent data
Data has shifted - since beginning of Oct spread has expanded from 0.05% to 0.16%.... economic conditions and relevant data suggests a more positive mood from investors
Spread is now 16 basis points for the 10yr - 2yr with 15 days left.  +13% to 'will not', -11% to 'between', -2% to 'more than'.

Still using a random walk model diff(day+1) = diff(day) + random_gaussian (mu=0, sigma) with sigma =  0.035, which might be too high.  This of course makes me think: I have only used a model and remained faithful to it, but it seems that I could have done a much better job if I had used more the inside view or something to adjust the probability buckets. The inversion of the yield curve is a psychological threshold probably, which maybe reduced it chances to be crossed. I will leave it as a mental note for future predictions.

trending upward.
13 bps Friday (bond markets closed today)

Continuing to reduce likelihood of an inversion over the next few weeks. Major developments on the trade front have created a risk-on mentality. Though it is likely this could deteriorate, the subsequent correction in yields would be unprecedented in a such a short amount of time.
Re-raising 'will not' significantly due to remaing time and diff between myself and the crowd. +30% to will not, -24% to lower, and -6% to between.
The spread between the 2 and 10 is 14 basis points at 1.59 and 1.73 respectively. -5% to 'lower', -2% to 'between', and +7% to 'will not'.
Spread was 6 or under from Sept 18the through Sept 30th; now closing between 10 and 15 for the last week.
Updating the forecast with passing of 1 week, and incorporating current spread at 12 bps.
I have no idea anymore... Really wasn't expecting this upswing, not expecting it to last but looking increasingly likely to survive the deadline...

The spread is barely 12 bps positive with 3 weeks to go.
Chairman Powell seems to want to intervene on the very short end by buying short Treasuries to provide overnight bank liquidity, and also reducing the reference rate.
Interestingly, the 10-yr/3-month spread is indeed negative, with the 3-month rate at 1.71% and the 10-year at 1.532%. This spread has been negative since late May - i think more from the demand by banks for overnight/short money (evidenced by bills) for reasons I do not fully understand---as it seems more of an accounting/balancing the books nightly kind-of-thing.
If Powell is able to influence the very short end - it should ripple up into the two-year ---- but that is a pretty long way up the yield curve - and I don't know how tight the correlation is between a move in the bills and the 2-year yield.
Nevertheless - incremental changes that this spread will not go negative.

The Fed is going to restart Open Market purchases to increase reserves in order to prevent challenges in the repo market. Powell indicated that these purchases will focus on the short end of the yield curve. https://www.wsj.com/articles/powell-says-federal-reserve-will-soon-announce-measures-to-increase-supply-of-bank-reserves-11570559401?emailToken=f468a029c20ee812b5a8784e229fecb5+VXoEY6Ka4jVgX3jx+o45N3iqtWg/6UwR5qmB9dO+71aDMga3bTh+DTrN7JlIgjLy6KvXYEnM4mJQtQxiBRlgEu40ljBlzdo9TAmqdF6CaKRd3tx+38HdL50ASmHXxeZXIk5fK6ZpvnJ13vrdKkXa8VdOnzsWJxvSKLDTLv4gZU%3D&reflink=article_copyURL_share On the surface, this will lower short term yields, while an expected rate cut (81% probability according to FedWatch) will raise long term rates.  My bet is for this to widen the 2-10 spread.
Long yields continue to drop further.
Ran new forecast based on most recent week's data.

Updated with the 03/10/2019 data. I am doing  a random walk simulation, in which the difference between the 10 and 2 yr yields changes by a random Gaussian number everyday: diff(day+1) = diff(day) + random_gaussian (mu=0, sigma) My predictions are the results from 03/10 onwards.

September 2019 had mostly single digit basis point spreads - if not at times actual negative spreads.
Equity market reactions of the past two days pushed the 10-2 spread to positive 12 basis points.
Still an abnormally tight spread historically.
For purposes of the question, 12 bps is a world away from inverted yields.
Nevertheless - we have a whole month of fun and fury that can tip this any which way.
The basis of the initial forecast still holds true.
Spread has widened to 15 bps today. Economic reports and further market weakness increases the odds of a Fed cut at month end, thereby steepening the short end of the yield curve.

Updated with the 02/10/2019 data: what I am doing is a random walk simulation, in which the difference between the 10 and 2 yr yields changes by a random Gaussian number everyday: diff(day+1) = diff(day) + random_gaussian (mu=0, sigma) Then I run 10k simulations and check in how many of them the different thresholds of the question are achieved. The problem is the selection of a suitable sigma (now I take 0.035%, previously I took a 0.04%, which might be too big).

2-10Y spreads have increased significantly since last week - now standing at 11.4 bps.  Based on this, a bigger decline in spread is required to move to the stated levels.  This lowers the probability this would be achieved.  Using only data in weekly change.
Widening spreads as short term rates have taken a step down
Currently the 10 is at 1.6 and the 2yr is at 1.48. A 12 bps spread. +12% to 'will not' -4% to 'between' and -8% to more than.

Stock markets just took a dump. Dow jones down 1.5%. I dont fully understand the relationship but i'd expect those selling stocks are putting their money in bonds... which will effect the yield somewhat.. i'd anticipate the 2 year would go up more than the 10.

Curve steepened a bunch yesterday into today. Spread now stands at 11 bps up from 4 just a few days ago. Weaker stock market and economic data increases the odds of Fed cutting on 10/30. That is currently weaving it's way into expectations and is being reflected in the steeper curve.

Updated with 01/10/2019 data (brief note: I am using basically a random walk model, where everyday I allow the difference to change by a random Gaussian amount; the main problem is adjusting the sigma of this random change).
Gonna be volatile and interesting in Oct.
Updated with the 30/09/2019 data. However, I am starting to think that I am assuming a too large variance for the daily drift.

The tricky part about this forecast is the end date. The fed meeting ending on 10/30 could impact the outcome in the final 36 hours. Will have a much better feel for what to expect from the Fed as we get closer to 10/30.

Spread is widening today in reaction to weak economic numbers. The market is recognizing the increased odds that the Fed will further cut ST rates and thereby steepen the yield curve. Also into October now so less time for the curve to invert before the 10/31 end date.

I look at the spreads for historical periods.  These are currently at levels close to zero, so using percentage change of spreads would yield volatile numbers.  Hence I use change of spreads over past periods.  I look at both weekly change and daily change.  There are 5 weeks from now to 2019 Oct 31st, or 25 trading days. The 2-10Y spread now is 3.637 bps.  For the 10Y to be 10 bps lower than the 2Y, we need a change of -13.64 bps.  For the difference to be 1 bp lower, the change would need to be -4.64 bps. From the raw data for both the change-over-5-weeks and change-over-25-days, I gathered that % of days where change is lower than -13.64 is around 19%.  For % of days where change is lower than -4.64 is around 47-48%.  I also checked normalized data, excluding a couple of outliers.  The results are consistent with that arrived at using raw data.
Get ready for a roller coaster ride on the bond market. Will need an update before the question closes.
Revised forecast  given last few days of data.  Will revise again, as needed
4 basis points separate the 10 and 2 narrowing in the last week. 1.71 and 1.67 respectively.
There are more factors pointing to no immediate economic downturn, than the other way round.

The inverted nature of the yield curve tends to be an indicator of global economic pessimism. The recent pessimism has been a function of the volatile trade talks between the US and its trading partners. The US administration has now given the indication that trade agreements may be coming sooner than later. If this is true, and further evidence presents itself in corroborating this, then pessimism should ease for the remainder of the year.
he 10 yr has not yet closed below the 2 yr yield. Currently, the spread is 4 basis points with the yields 1.77 and 1.73 respectively.

the majority of the time the 10 year yield is higher than the 2 year.  Though there are many clouds on the economic  horizon leading indicators are not showing too much stress. Also, the odds should be on a positive US/China resolution trade resolution. Finally, the Fed rate cut yesterday provides some stimulus which should provide upward momentum to longer term yields as opposed to short term.(though that is not the case this morning)
The spread has been steadily declining and the Fed has just announced that they will be lowering interest rates.
2 yr rose to 1.77% today, 10 yr down to 1.80%.

Okay, the Fed decreased the interest rate, but the closing spread today narrowed to 0.03. Going to broaden and hedge for a "accidental" negative spread due to noisy fluctuations, until the "normal" market reaction to falling short term rates can happen.

Adjusting previous forecast slightly as reading it back I feel it was slightly overconfident, and previous forecasts and forecast practice showed I have a tendency for overconfidence: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/906536

Note to start: Fellow forecasters, is it just me or are the answer options for this question not collectively exhaustive? The way I see it, if the 10 yr yield closes at the 2 year yield and that is the lowest spread in the question timeframe, none of the answers apply. Granted, since 1990 there have only been 21 days on which the 10yr yield closed at the 2yr yield, or 0.28% of days, but nevertheless, it happens. Please let me know your thoughts. As for the forecast:
----
Base rates
----
Raw data source: [1] ----
36 business day periods (like the question period) with the lowest spread being a (all data since 2019-01-02):
Positive spread (bucket A): 89.2%
Zero spread (no bucket): 0.1%
-0.01 to -0.10 spread (bucket B): 4.5%
lower than -0.1 spread (bucket C): 6.2% Limiting to periods where the spread was between -1 and 1:
Positive spread (bucket A): 76.1%
Zero spread (no bucket), 0.3%
-0.01 to -0.10 spread (bucket B): 10.0%
lower than -0.1 spread (bucket C): 13.7% Limiting to periods where the spread was between -0.5 to 0.5:
Positive spread (bucket A): 65.5%
Zero spread (no bucket), 0.4%
-0.01 to -0.10 spread (bucket B): 14.5%
lower than -0.1 spread (bucket C): 19.7% ---- Frequencies of days with closing spreads in the buckets plus zero spread (all data since 2019-01-02):
Positive spread (bucket A): 92.8%
Zero spread (no bucket), 0.3%
-0.01 to -0.10 spread (bucket B): 3.0%
lower than -0.1 spread (bucket C): 3.9% Limiting to periods where the spread was between -1 and 1:
Positive spread (bucket A): 84.3%
Zero spread (no bucket), 0.6%
-0.01 to -0.10 spread (bucket B): 6.5%
lower than -0.1 spread (bucket C): 8.6% Limiting to periods where the spread was between -0.5 to 0.5:
Positive spread (bucket A): 77.5%
Zero spread (no bucket), 0.9%
-0.01 to -0.10 spread (bucket B): 9.3%
lower than -0.1 spread (bucket C): 12.3% --- Insights from the base rates:
- negative spreads are infrequent events (<10% of 36 day periods and and <7% of all days since the start of 1990)
- if the spread goes negative, a spread <-0.1 (bucket C) is more likely to be the lowest spread than -0.01 to -0.1 (bucket B) , historical ratio bucket C/B ~1.3
- I am not sure whether limiting to periods of lower spreads brings any additional conclusions, or should even be considered a relevant base rate. ---
Inside view:
The Fed is expected to lower interest rates, which should put downward pressure 2yr treasury yields. They seem to be prepared to lower rates again this year.[2] In my opinion, forward guidance puts pressure on the Fed to go through with what they said, as anything else is feared to shake up markets. In addition, President Trump keeps pushing his message for more significant rate cuts - one can re-iterate the independence of the Fed again and again, I still believe this has an influence on the decision process. --- 
Crowd: 52, 37, 11

[2] https://eu.usatoday.com/story/money/2019/09/17/interest-rates-fed-expected-cut-key-rate-wednesday/2347263001/

I have updated my results (the previous contained a really trivial mistake in the calculation).
I will start with a naive “chimp” forecast and update accordingly.
The trend is negative and the next inflation data will not consent the Federal Reserve to be very dovish.

Need to do some deeper analysis, but upticks in the stock market are not being reflected in bonds and a bubble seems to exist in US debt that is causing negative real yields. I think aggressive easing by the Fed is supporting the long end of the curve, but there are still technical factors (duration and convexity hedging) at play that could keep yields low. Trade was risks also persist. My base case is for an inversion given fundamentals, trade worries, and demand for US debt. I see more risk to this view on the upside given the current spread and short timeframe til question ends

Looking at this based on the current state of China. Significant unrest in HK, political tensions escalating domestically, the West using China's unrest as a point of leverage by demonizing China for their treatment of citizens and exacerbating the issue , China's focus shifting between domestic issues and trade tensions with US.  Overall, unless in the next week, there is a significant turnaround in HK, I do not foresee much changing from where we are at today.

We currently have a +.053 spread  - no yield curve inversion.
It follows a substantial reversal from the -.053 spread of Aug 26 or so.
Both the 2-year and the 10-year have now had their yields move strongly and suddenly upwards since Sep 4/5.
This reversal feels like "risk-on" by traders more than it does any statement either way about the economy.
Using TLT (20-year treasuries) as my guide - we're at a level of support presently at 139.50 - but it played weakly today. I'm no technician - but next level of support seems to be 130 - which translates to a yield of 2.68% from today's 2.49% if TLT continues to fall in price this week and next. 
And if TLT does continue to fall in price,  I'd expect the 10-year yield to move upwards in similar fashion, while the two-year rate will be biased downwards because of Fed rate cutting.
Thus, a likelihood of continued positive spread through Oct 31.
Let's see what happens.....
i have started this by the way, now i am going to read about this, i will change my forecast in a little time.

Asking for the widest closing spread below 2 year bonds... when -0.04 has already been reached in August and this is for an 8 week period. I'm assuming this is a per day measurement...?  Would be crazy to say it will not drop below the 2 year yield when its already been breached 3 days in the past month. Nice research  @Mervatronicus

There has been a continued compression of the spread since July - see link - with 6 days in which the yield curve inverted or was at 0%  
https://ycharts.com/indicators/10_2_year_treasury_yield_spread  There is a chance that FED communications do impact market confidence - as has been seen since Powell took over from Yellen and because the market has decided to test his resolve on numerous occasions - I have tried to factor in potential emotional response from market participants - and continued flurry of Trump tweets that hardly promote confidence in his [own] FED decision maker - as some commentators push the idea that inverted yield curve is a precursor to recession - old adage that market can talk itself into recession even if the data suggests otherwise is a concern - however as the US economy [at the moment] is not signalling imminent recession warning in the most recent set of economic data  - until China trade risk as well as other psychological issues that investors are currently facing are resolved I do think there is an increased chance of further inversion over the next 6-8 weeks -  [to be updated]
I already hate this question, but you gotta start someplace.

Official forecasts of recession that I respect are still below 25%.   The inversion seems to have been an overreaction to trade tensions. Current spread is 7 basis points, up from a negative reading only days ago.  With only weeks to go in the question, I think a double-digit spread is a good bet.
